snippet: Issues of race, policing and gun rights have turned into a volatile mix after officer-involved shootings of black men and the killing and wounding of officers by snipers at a protest....
abstract: African-Americans who legally own guns weigh benefits of ownership following instances in Dallas and Minnesota where police misread intentions of lawfully armed blacks; experts on bias say negative stereotypes may put blacks at greater risk of having their actions misinterpreted; Yafeuh Balogun, founder of Dallas gun club that promotes African-American gun ownership, says his members use extraordinary precautions in Texas, where it is legal to openly carry firearms.

byline.original: By JOHN ELIGON and FRANCES ROBLES

lead_paragraph: Issues of race, policing and gun rights have turned into a volatile mix after officer-involved shootings of black men and the killing and wounding of officers by snipers at a protest.

headline.main: Police Shootings Highlight Unease Among Black Gun Owners
headline.print_headline: Opportunity or Liability? After Shootings, Black Gun Owners Weigh Firearm Benefits
